sentences: Harvard-MIT Division of Health Sciences and Technology
What should one look for in the placenta?
When should one request placental pathology
Basically - all placentas should receive a pathologic examination except:
[LIST_ITEM] Term singletons to normal healthy moms that had prenatal care and delivered in the hospital by a certified clinician and went home with mom on the appropriate d/c day!!
[LIST_ITEM] What is important in the gross exam
[LIST_ITEM] What is important in the histologic exam
[LIST_ITEM] BOTH maternal and fetal side tissues!
Findings with immediate prognostic implications for infant
[LIST_ITEM] Fetal response to acute chorioamnionitis includes:
[LIST_ITEM] Inflammatory cells migrating from fetal vessels
[LIST_ITEM] "Vasculitis" is a risk factor for neurodevelopmental delay/cerebral palsy
[LIST_ITEM] Most are non-infectious (Villitis of unclear etiology - VUE)
[LIST_ITEM] ~1/3 recur and if recur associated with ~2/3 risk of IUFD or IUGR
[LIST_ITEM] Occurs in primary or recurrent infection in Mom
[LIST_ITEM] Common after 40 weeks NOT a sign of fetal distress
[LIST_ITEM] Before 40 weeks can implicate fetal distress
[LIST_ITEM] Histologic findings can be correlated with length of time of exposure
[LIST_ITEM] Takes AT MINIMUM 1 hour to see meconium grossly or in the amnion
[LIST_ITEM] Takes AT MINIMUM 3 hours to see pigment in chorion
[LIST_ITEM] Takes AT MINIMUM 6 hours to see ulceration of amnion
[LIST_ITEM] Takes AT MINIMUM 12 hours to see in Wharton's jelly of umbilical cord
[LIST_ITEM] Takes AT MINIMUM 18 hours to see myonecrosis
[LIST_ITEM] Thrombosis in fetal vessels of placenta
[LIST_ITEM] Vascular damage due to fetal inflammation
[H1] Placental findings with prognostic implications for mother.
[LIST_ITEM] Diagnosis depends on gross and histologic exam
[LIST_ITEM] Basal villi of entire maternal floor encased by perivillous fibrinoid of â‰¥ 3mm thick
